maml:description.maml:para: Register script metadata in $global:DevRunScripts registry.
Stores script metadata (text, timestamp, exit code, dependencies) in the global script registry. This enables script invocation, chaining, and tracking of script execution history.
Typically called automatically by Invoke-DevRun, but can be used manually to register scripts for invocation.
Script name (used as registry key).
PowerShell script text to store.
Exit code from last execution (default: 0).
Optional array of script names this script depends on.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Script name (used as registry key).
PowerShell script text to store.
Exit code from last execution (default: 0).
Optional array of script names this script depends on.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Overwrites existing script with same name. Use Get-DevScripts to list registered scripts.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Add-DevScript -Name "build" -Script "dotnet build" Registered script 'build'

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Add-DevScript -Name "test" -Script "dotnet test" -Dependencies @("build") Registered script 'test' with dependency on 'build'

maml:description.maml:para: Clear cached DevRun data.
Invalidates cache entries for DevRun stream data. Useful after running Invoke-DevRun again with same name to ensure fresh data is loaded.
Can clear specific script's cache or all cached data.
Script name to clear from cache. If omitted, clears all cache entries.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Script name to clear from cache. If omitted, clears all cache entries.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Does not affect $env storage - only in-memory cache. Next Get-CachedStreamData call will reload from $env.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Clear-DevRunCache -Name "build" Clears cached data for "build" script only

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Clear-DevRunCache Clears all cached DevRun data

maml:description.maml:para: Clear stored results from BrickStore.
Removes stored analysis results from BrickStore. Useful for cleaning up after analysis sessions or freeing memory.
Can clear specific result by name or all results.
Name of specific result to clear. If omitted, clears all results.
Also clear all learned patterns (use with caution).
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Name of specific result to clear. If omitted, clears all results.
Also clear all learned patterns (use with caution).
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Does not affect saved .brickyard.json files. Use Save-Project before clearing if you want to preserve patterns.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Clear-Stored -Name "build" Cleared stored result: build

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Clear-Stored Cleared all stored results (3 items)

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Clear-Stored -Patterns Cleared all stored results and patterns WARNING: This removes all learned patterns!

maml:description.maml:para: Export current PowerShell session environment variables to JSON/script format.
Captures and exports the current PowerShell session's environment variables. Useful for debugging MCP server sessions, documenting build environments, or reproducing development environments.
Can export to JSON (default), PowerShell script, or display to console.
Output file path. File extension determines format: - .json: JSON format (default)
- .ps1: PowerShell script format (executable)
- Omit for console output
Filter to include only matching variables (wildcard supported). Example: "PWSH_ ", "PATH", "CONDA_ "
Filter to exclude matching variables (wildcard supported). Example: " TOKEN ", " SECRET ", " PASSWORD "
Output format: 'JSON', 'PowerShell', 'Console'. Auto-detected from file extension if Path provided.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Output file path. File extension determines format: - .json: JSON format (default)
- .ps1: PowerShell script format (executable)
- Omit for console output
Filter to include only matching variables (wildcard supported). Example: "PWSH_ ", "PATH", "CONDA_ "
Filter to exclude matching variables (wildcard supported). Example: " TOKEN ", " SECRET ", " PASSWORD "
Output format: 'JSON', 'PowerShell', 'Console'. Auto-detected from file extension if Path provided.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: JSON format preserves exact values for machine parsing. PowerShell format creates executable script with $env: assignments. Always exclude sensitive data before sharing exports.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Export-Environment Displays all environment variables to console

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Export-Environment -Path "env-snapshot.json" Exports all environment variables to JSON file

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Export-Environment -Path "restore-env.ps1" Creates executable PowerShell script to restore environment

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Export-Environment -Include "PWSH_*","PYTHON*" -Path "mcp-env.json" Exports only MCP-related environment variables

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 5 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Export-Environment -Exclude "*TOKEN*","*SECRET*" -Path "safe-env.json" Exports environment excluding sensitive variables

maml:description.maml:para: Save results to file in various formats.
Exports pipeline input to a file in specified format (text, csv, json, xml). Provides a consistent interface for saving analysis results with automatic format detection from file extension.
Particularly useful for saving analysis results for later review, sharing with team members, or importing into other tools.
Output file path. Format auto-detected from extension if not specified.
Objects to export.
Output format: 'text', 'csv', 'json', 'xml'. Auto-detects from extension if omitted.
Append to file instead of overwriting. Only applies to text format.
Fail if file already exists instead of overwriting.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Objects to export.
Output file path. Format auto-detected from extension if not specified.
Output format: 'text', 'csv', 'json', 'xml'. Auto-detects from extension if omitted.
Append to file instead of overwriting. Only applies to text format.
Fail if file already exists instead of overwriting.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Creates parent directory if it doesn't exist. CSV format requires objects (not plain strings).

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Find-Errors build.log | Export-ToFile errors.csv # Auto-detects CSV format from extension

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-BuildError gcc.log | Export-ToFile build-errors.json -Format json # Explicit JSON format

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Find-Warnings app.log | Export-ToFile warnings.txt -Format text # Plain text output (one item per line)

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-Process | Select-Object Name, CPU | Export-ToFile processes.xml # Export as XML

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 5 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Find-Errors test1.log | Export-ToFile all-errors.txt -Append PS> Find-Errors test2.log | Export-ToFile all-errors.txt -Append # Accumulate errors from multiple sources

maml:description.maml:para: Extract and count errors from text output.

Searches input text for error patterns and returns frequency analysis of errors found. By default, uses common error keywords (error, exception, failed, failure) but supports custom patterns for project-specific error formats.
Results are automatically grouped and sorted by frequency, making it easy to identify the most common errors in build logs, test output, or application logs.
Text to search. Can be array of strings, file content, or pipeline input.
Custom regex pattern for matching errors. Default: \b(error|exception|failed|failure)\b
Make pattern matching case-sensitive. Default is case-insensitive.
Return only top N most frequent errors. Default is all errors.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Path to file to analyze. Alternative to piping content.
Custom regex pattern for matching errors. Default: \b(error|exception|failed|failure)\b
Make pattern matching case-sensitive. Default is case-insensitive.
Return only top N most frequent errors. Default is all errors.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Text to search. Can be array of strings, file content, or pipeline input.
Path to file to analyze. Alternative to piping content.
Custom regex pattern for matching errors. Default: \b(error|exception|failed|failure)\b
Make pattern matching case-sensitive. Default is case-insensitive.
Return only top N most frequent errors. Default is all errors.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Returns PSCustomObject with Count and Item properties for easy formatting. Blank lines and non-matching lines are ignored.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Find-Errors build.log 42x: error: Cannot find module 'foo' 12x: error: Undefined variable 'bar' 3x: error: Type mismatch

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-Content test-output.txt | Find-Errors -Top 5 # Show only top 5 most common errors

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Find-Errors app.log -Pattern "FATAL|ERROR|EXCEPTION" # Custom pattern for Java-style logging

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $env:build_stderr | Find-Errors | Format-Count -Width 4 # Analyze errors from dev-run stored output

maml:description.maml:para: Extract and count warnings from text output.
Searches input text for warning patterns and returns frequency analysis of warnings found. Similar to Find-Errors but specifically targets warning-level messages.
By default matches common warning keywords, but supports custom patterns for language-specific or tool-specific warning formats.
Text to search. Can be array of strings, file content, or pipeline input.
Custom regex pattern for matching warnings. Default: \bwarning\b
Make pattern matching case-sensitive. Default is case-insensitive.
Return only top N most frequent warnings. Default is all warnings.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Path to file to analyze. Alternative to piping content.
Custom regex pattern for matching warnings. Default: \bwarning\b
Make pattern matching case-sensitive. Default is case-insensitive.
Return only top N most frequent warnings. Default is all warnings.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Text to search. Can be array of strings, file content, or pipeline input.
Path to file to analyze. Alternative to piping content.
Custom regex pattern for matching warnings. Default: \bwarning\b
Make pattern matching case-sensitive. Default is case-insensitive.
Return only top N most frequent warnings. Default is all warnings.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Returns PSCustomObject with Count and Item properties. Particularly useful for code quality analysis and identifying common code smells.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Find-Warnings build.log 15x: warning: Unused variable 'temp' 8x: warning: Deprecated function usage 3x: warning: Missing semicolon

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-Content compiler.log | Find-Warnings -Pattern "warning (C\d+):" | Format-Count # Extract MSVC warning codes

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Find-Warnings eslint-output.txt -Top 10 # Show top 10 ESLint warnings

maml:description.maml:para: Format items with count prefix.
Formats frequency count results as "count x: item" with aligned counts. Useful for showing aggregated error/warning counts from build logs or test output.
Expects input objects with Count and Item properties (typically from Measure-Frequency or Group-Object with count). Passes through objects without these properties unchanged.
Object with Count and Item (or Name) properties from Measure-Frequency or Group-Object.
Width of count column for alignment (default: 6). Adjust based on expected count magnitude.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Object with Count and Item (or Name) properties from Measure-Frequency or Group-Object.
Width of count column for alignment (default: 6). Adjust based on expected count magnitude.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Pipeline-friendly: Processes each input object individually for streaming efficiency.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-Content build.log | Select-String "error" | Measure-Frequency | Format-Count 42x: Cannot find module 'foo' 12x: Undefined variable 'bar' 3x: Type mismatch in assignment

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Find-Errors build.log | Format-Count -Width 4 42x: Cannot find module 'foo' 12x: Undefined variable 'bar'

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: "error: foo", "error: bar", "error: foo" | Measure-Frequency | Format-Count 2x: error: foo 1x: error: bar

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieve background process output from DevRun cache.
Convenience wrapper over Get-StreamData for background processes. Retrieves captured output for analysis with AgentBlocks functions.
Functionally identical to Get-StreamData - use whichever feels more natural. This function exists for semantic clarity when working with background processes.
Name of background process (from Invoke-BackgroundProcess).
Which stream to retrieve (Error, Warning, Output, etc.).
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Name of background process (from Invoke-BackgroundProcess).
Which stream to retrieve (Error, Warning, Output, etc.).
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Alias for Get-StreamData - use whichever is clearer in context. Requires Stop-BackgroundProcess to have been called first to populate cache.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-BackgroundData build Error | Find-Errors | Format-Count

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: # Equivalent to Get-StreamData Get-BackgroundData test Error | Group-BuildErrors Get-StreamData test Error | Group-BuildErrors

maml:description.maml:para: Display current BrickStore state (patterns, results, chains).
Shows overview of current BrickStore state including registered patterns, stored results from dev-run, and saved analysis chains.
Useful for understanding what patterns and data are available for analysis.
Filter patterns by category.
Show detailed information including full regex patterns.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Filter patterns by category.
Show detailed information including full regex patterns.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Returns summary object with counts and lists.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-BrickStore
BrickStore State ================ Patterns: 15 Results: 3 Chains: 0
Recent Patterns: ESLint (lint) Pytest (test) MSBuild-Error (error)

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-BrickStore -Detailed # Shows full pattern details

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-BrickStore -Category error # Show only error patterns

maml:description.maml:para: Get build errors from common build tools (MSBuild, GCC, CMake, etc.).
Analyzes build output from various compilers and build systems, extracting structured error information including file, line, column, error code, and message.
Automatically detects output format from common build tools: - MSBuild/Visual Studio: file(line,col): error C####: message
- GCC/Clang: file:line:col: error: message
- CMake: CMake Error at file:line (function): message
- Maven/Gradle: [ERROR] message
Returns structured objects for easy filtering and analysis.
Build output text. Can be piped from Get-Content or stored dev-run output.
Hint about build tool type: 'MSBuild', 'GCC', 'CMake', 'Maven'. Auto-detects if omitted.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Path to build log file. Alternative to piping content.
Hint about build tool type: 'MSBuild', 'GCC', 'CMake', 'Maven'. Auto-detects if omitted.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Build output text. Can be piped from Get-Content or stored dev-run output.
Path to build log file. Alternative to piping content.
Hint about build tool type: 'MSBuild', 'GCC', 'CMake', 'Maven'. Auto-detects if omitted.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Returns PSCustomObject with File, Line, Col, Code, Message properties. Not all fields available for all build tools (e.g., Maven errors lack file/line).

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-BuildError build.log
File Line Col Code Message ---- ---- --- ---- ------- Program.cs 42 15 CS0103 The name 'foo' does not exist Utils.cs 128 8 CS0029 Cannot convert type 'int' to 'string'

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-Content cmake-output.txt | Get-BuildError -ToolType CMake # Parse CMake configure errors

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $env:build_stderr | Get-BuildError | Where-Object { $_.Code -like "CS*" } # Filter C# compiler errors from dev-run output

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-BuildError gcc.log | Group-Object File | Sort-Object Count -Descending # Find files with most errors

maml:description.maml:para: Get stream data from cache, warming from $env JSON if needed.

Retrieves stream data with cache-first strategy: 1. Check $global:DevRunCache for cached data 2. If miss, load from $env:{name}_streams JSON 3. Cache the parsed data for future access 4. Return requested stream
Significantly faster than parsing JSON on every Get-StreamData call.
Script name (e.g., "build" from Invoke-DevRun -Name build).
Stream to retrieve: Error, Warning, Verbose, Debug, Information, Output.
Force reload from $env (invalidate cache).
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Script name (e.g., "build" from Invoke-DevRun -Name build).
Stream to retrieve: Error, Warning, Verbose, Debug, Information, Output.
Force reload from $env (invalidate cache).
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Cache automatically invalidated when Invoke-DevRun executes with same name. Use -Force to manually invalidate (e.g., if cache was modified externally).

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-CachedStreamData -Name "build" -Stream Error Returns cached Error stream for "build" script

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-CachedStreamData -Name "build" -Stream Error -Force Invalidates cache and reloads from $env:build_streams

maml:description.maml:para: List all cached execution entries with metadata.
Shows cache names, timestamps, and output line counts for all cached executions in current session.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Shows metadata only, not full output. Use Get-DevRunOutput to retrieve data.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-DevRunCacheList # Returns: Table of cached entries
Name Timestamp StdoutLines ErrorCount WarningCount ---- --------- ----------- ---------- ------------ build 2025-11-22 23:45:12 847 12 5 test 2025-11-22 23:46:30 234 0 2

maml:description.maml:para: Display DevRun cache statistics.
Shows overview of current cache state including cached scripts count, script registry count, and lists of cached names.
Useful for debugging cache behavior and understanding cache hit patterns.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Does not show cache memory usage (future enhancement).

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-DevRunCacheStats
DevRun Cache Statistics ======================= Cached Streams: 3 Script Registry: 2
Cached Scripts: build test analyze
Registered Scripts: build (2024-11-18 12:34:56) test (2024-11-18 12:40:12)

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieve cached output from previous Invoke-DevRun or pwsh tool execution.
Gets full output from cached execution. Useful for detailed analysis after reviewing condensed summary from Invoke-DevRun.
All pwsh tool executions (with or without mode='Invoke-DevRun') are auto-cached and retrievable via this function.
Cache name to retrieve. Use Get-DevRunCacheList to see available names.
Which output to retrieve: - Stdout: Regular command output (default)
- Stderr: Error stream output
- Error, Warning, Verbose, Debug, Information, Progress: PowerShell streams
- All: Complete cached object with all data and metadata
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Cache name to retrieve. Use Get-DevRunCacheList to see available names.
Which output to retrieve: - Stdout: Regular command output (default)
- Stderr: Error stream output
- Error, Warning, Verbose, Debug, Information, Progress: PowerShell streams
- All: Complete cached object with all data and metadata
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Cache persists for session lifetime. Use Export-Environment to save to disk.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-DevRunOutput -Name 'build' -Stream 'Error' # Returns: Array of all error messages from 'build' execution

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-DevRunOutput -Name 'build' -Stream 'All' # Returns: Complete cache entry with Script, Timestamp, and all streams

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-DevRunOutput -Name 'build' -Stream 'Stdout' | Select-String 'warning' # Pipe stdout to further analysis

maml:description.maml:para: List all registered scripts with metadata.
Displays all scripts in $global:DevRunScripts registry with their metadata including timestamp, exit code, and dependencies.
Useful for discovering available scripts for invocation and chaining.
Filter to specific script name. If omitted, shows all scripts.
Show full script text and all metadata.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Filter to specific script name. If omitted, shows all scripts.
Show full script text and all metadata.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Scripts registered automatically by Invoke-DevRun or manually via Add-DevScript.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-DevScripts
Registered Scripts (3) ====================== Name Timestamp ExitCode Dependencies ---- --------- -------- ------------ build 2024-11-18 12:34:56 0 test 2024-11-18 12:40:12 0 build deploy 2024-11-18 13:15:30 1 build, test

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-DevScripts -Name "build" -Detailed
Name: build Script: dotnet build Timestamp: 2024-11-18 12:34:56 ExitCode: 0 Dependencies: (none)

maml:description.maml:para: Calculate Jaro-Winkler similarity distance between two strings.

Computes Jaro-Winkler distance (0.0 to 1.0) measuring string similarity. Values closer to 1.0 indicate higher similarity. Useful for fuzzy matching of error messages, file names, or other text where exact matches aren't required.
Jaro-Winkler gives higher scores to strings with matching prefixes, making it particularly effective for matching error messages with similar patterns.
First string to compare.
Second string to compare.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
First string to compare.
Second string to compare.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Returns 1.0 for identical strings, 0.0 for completely dissimilar strings. Threshold of 0.85 works well for grouping similar error messages.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-JaroWinklerDistance "The name 'foo' does not exist" "The name 'bar' does not exist" 0.924

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-JaroWinklerDistance "error CS0103" "error CS0168" 0.733

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieve specific stream data from Invoke-DevRun cached storage.
Extracts a specific PowerShell stream (Error, Warning, Verbose, Debug, Information, Output) from DevRun cache ($global:DevRunCache). Returns raw array of stream items for pipeline processing.
Uses $global:DevRunCache for performance - first access loads and caches data, subsequent accesses retrieve from cache (much faster for repeated queries).
Used to access individual streams from Invoke-DevRun results for post-hoc analysis. Complements Show-StreamSummary which displays formatted summaries.
Name used in Invoke-DevRun (e.g., "build" for Invoke-DevRun -Name build).
Stream to retrieve: Error, Warning, Verbose, Debug, Information, or Output.
Force reload from cache (invalidate local copy). Use if cache was modified externally.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Name used in Invoke-DevRun (e.g., "build" for Invoke-DevRun -Name build).
Stream to retrieve: Error, Warning, Verbose, Debug, Information, or Output.
Force reload from cache (invalidate local copy). Use if cache was modified externally.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Requires Invoke-DevRun to have been executed with stream storage enabled (default behavior). Returns $null if name or stream not found. Cache automatically invalidated when Invoke-DevRun executes with same name. Performance: ~10-100x faster for repeated access (no JSON parsing).

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-StreamData -Name "build" -Stream Error file.cs(10): error CS0103: The name 'foo' does not exist file.cs(42): error CS0168: Variable declared but not used

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
-------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-StreamData -Name "build" -Stream Error | Group-BuildErrors | Format-Table Count Code Files Message ----- ---- ----- ------- 2 CS0103 2 The name 'foo' does not exist 1 CS0168 1 Variable declared but not used

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-StreamData -Name "build" -Stream Error -Force # Forces reload from cache (local copy bypassed)

maml:description.maml:para: Group build errors by code and similar messages using pattern extraction.

Extracts structured error information using regex patterns, groups by error code, then fuzzy-matches error messages within each code group. Produces a clean summary showing error frequency, codes, and representative messages.
More powerful than Group-Similar alone because it first extracts semantic structure (file, line, code, message) before grouping.
Error text lines (e.g., from build logs).
Pattern name from Get-Patterns. Default: "MSBuild-Error". Supports: MSBuild-Error, GCC, Clang, etc.
Similarity threshold for message fuzzy matching. Default: 0.85.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Error text lines (e.g., from build logs).
Pattern name from Get-Patterns. Default: "MSBuild-Error". Supports: MSBuild-Error, GCC, Clang, etc.
Similarity threshold for message fuzzy matching. Default: 0.85.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Requires AgentBlocks patterns to be loaded (Get-Patterns). Pattern must have named groups: file, line, code, message.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-StreamData -Name "build" -Stream Error | Group-BuildErrors Count Code Files Message ----- ---- ----- ------- 3 CS0103 3 The name 'foo' does not exist 2 CS0168 2 Variable declared but not used

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-Content gcc.log | Group-BuildErrors -Pattern "GCC" Count Code Files Message ----- ---- ----- ------- 12 error 5 undefined reference to 'foo' 3 warning 2 unused variable 'bar'

maml:description.maml:para: Group objects by property value.
Groups input objects by a specified property, returning objects with Count and Item properties. Wrapper around Group-Object that returns a more pipeline-friendly format with sorted results.
Results are sorted by count (descending) by default, making it easy to identify most frequent values.
Property name to group by. Can be a simple property name or nested property path.
Objects to group. Typically piped in from previous command.
Skip sorting by count. Returns groups in order encountered.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Property name to group by. Can be a simple property name or nested property path.
Objects to group. Typically piped in from previous command.
Skip sorting by count. Returns groups in order encountered.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Output format: PSCustomObject with Count and Item properties for easy consumption by Format-Count.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-ChildItem | Group-By Extension 42x: .txt 12x: .log 3x: .md

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-Content errors.log | Select-String "file: (\S+)" | ForEach-Object { $_.Matches.Groups[1].Value } | Group-By 15x: app.js 8x: utils.js 2x: config.json

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Import-Csv log.csv | Group-By Level | Format-Count 245x: ERROR 89x: WARN 12x: INFO

maml:description.maml:para: Group similar items using fuzzy string matching.
Groups items by similarity using Jaro-Winkler distance. Items above the similarity threshold are grouped together, with the first item in each group becoming the exemplar.
Particularly useful for grouping error messages that differ only in variable names, line numbers, or other minor variations.
Items to group. Can be strings or objects (use -Property for objects).
Similarity threshold (0.0-1.0). Items with similarity >= threshold are grouped together. Default: 0.85 (85% similar).
Property name to compare for object inputs. If omitted, compares entire object as string.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Items to group. Can be strings or objects (use -Property for objects).
Similarity threshold (0.0-1.0). Items with similarity >= threshold are grouped together. Default: 0.85 (85% similar).
Property name to compare for object inputs. If omitted, compares entire object as string.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Groups are sorted by count (descending). Each group includes: - Count: Number of items in group
- Example: Exemplar item (first in group)
- Items: All items in the group

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
-------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-StreamData -Name "build" -Stream Error | Group-Similar | Format-Count 42x: error CS0103: The name 'X' does not exist 8x: error CS0168: Variable declared but not used

maml:description.maml:para: Import patterns and state from .brickyard.json file.

Loads previously saved patterns from a .brickyard.json file into the current BrickStore. This enables restoring learned patterns across sessions or importing patterns from other projects/team members.
Automatically called during module import if .brickyard.json exists in current directory.
Input file path. Defaults to .brickyard.json in current directory.
Merge with existing patterns instead of replacing. Default is replace.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Input file path. Defaults to .brickyard.json in current directory.
Merge with existing patterns instead of replacing. Default is replace.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Validates pattern syntax before loading. Warns if patterns have duplicate names (when merging).

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Import-Project Loaded 15 patterns from .brickyard.json

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Import-Project -Path "~/shared-patterns.json" -Merge # Merge patterns from shared library

maml:description.maml:para: Start external process in background with output capture to DevRun cache.

Runs process in background, capturing stdout/stderr to temporary files. Compatible with DevRun cache ($global:DevRunCache) - use Stop-BackgroundProcess to move output to cache for analysis with Get-StreamData, Get-BuildError, Group-BuildErrors, etc.
After stopping, output is stored in $global:DevRunCache using the same format as Invoke-DevRun, making background process output compatible with all Base/AgentBlocks analysis functions.
Unique name for this background process (used as DevRun cache key).
Executable to run (e.g., 'dotnet', 'python', 'node').
Arguments for the executable.
Working directory for process (defaults to current location).
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Unique name for this background process (used as DevRun cache key).
PowerShell script to run in background (alternative to FilePath). Use here-strings (@'...'@) for multi-line scripts.
Working directory for process (defaults to current location).
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Unique name for this background process (used as DevRun cache key).
Executable to run (e.g., 'dotnet', 'python', 'node').
Arguments for the executable.
PowerShell script to run in background (alternative to FilePath). Use here-strings (@'...'@) for multi-line scripts.
Working directory for process (defaults to current location).
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Integrates with DevRun cache system ($global:DevRunCache). After Stop-BackgroundProcess, use Get-StreamData to retrieve output for analysis with all Base/AgentBlocks functions.
Process output captured to temp files during execution, moved to DevRun cache on stop for compatibility with Get-StreamData, Get-BuildError, etc.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# Start dev server $serverCode = @' dotnet run --project Server.csproj --urls http://localhost:5000 '@ Invoke-BackgroundProcess -Name 'devserver' -Script $serverCode
# Do work...
# Stop and analyze Stop-BackgroundProcess -Name 'devserver' Get-StreamData devserver Error | Find-Errors | Format-Count

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# Start build watcher Invoke-BackgroundProcess -Name 'watcher' -FilePath 'npm' -ArgumentList 'run', 'watch'
# Later... Stop-BackgroundProcess -Name 'watcher' Get-StreamData watcher Output | Select-RegexMatch -Pattern 'compiled' | Measure-Frequency

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# Multiple background processes $buildCode = @' dotnet watch build '@ Invoke-BackgroundProcess -Name 'build' -Script $buildCode
$testCode = @' dotnet watch test '@ Invoke-BackgroundProcess -Name 'test' -Script $testCode
Test-BackgroundProcess -Name 'build' Test-BackgroundProcess -Name 'test'

maml:description.maml:para: Execute PowerShell script with stream capture, caching, and condensed summary output.
Runs PowerShell script in current session, captures all output streams, stores in $global:DevRunCache, and returns token-efficient summary (error/warning counts, top issues).

Auto-caches ALL executions for later retrieval via Get-DevRunOutput. Use this for build commands, tests, linting - any script where you want results summarized but need full output available for analysis.
Default behavior: - Returns condensed 15-line summary (99% token reduction vs full output)
- Caches full output in $global:DevRunCache[name]
- Shows Error and Warning streams in summary
- Mutes Verbose, Debug, Information (available in cache)
PowerShell script to execute. Can be command, pipeline, or multi-line script.
Cache name for storing results. REQUIRED. Results stored in $global:DevRunCache[name] with Script, Timestamp, and all stream data.
PowerShell streams to include in summary. Default: Error, Warning. Valid: Error, Warning, Verbose, Debug, Information, Progress, Output
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
PowerShell script to execute. Can be command, pipeline, or multi-line script.
Cache name for storing results. REQUIRED. Results stored in $global:DevRunCache[name] with Script, Timestamp, and all stream data.
PowerShell streams to include in summary. Default: Error, Warning. Valid: Error, Warning, Verbose, Debug, Information, Progress, Output
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Cache persists for session lifetime. Use Clear-DevRunCache to free memory. Use Export-Environment to save cache to disk for later sessions.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-DevRun -Script 'dotnet build' -Name 'build' # Returns: # Script: dotnet build # # Errors: 12 (3 unique) # Top Errors: # 8x: CS0246: The type or namespace name 'Foo' could not be found # 3x: CS1002: ; expected # 1x: CS0103: The name 'bar' does not exist # # Warnings: 5 (2 unique) # ... # Output: 847 lines # # Stored: $global:DevRunCache['build'] # Retrieve: Get-DevRunOutput -Name 'build' -Stream 'Error'

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-DevRun -Script 'Get-Process | Where CPU -gt 100' -Name 'highcpu' # Executes and caches. Full output available via Get-DevRunOutput.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-DevRun -Script 'npm test' -Name 'test' -Streams @('Error','Warning','Verbose') # Include Verbose stream in summary

maml:description.maml:para: Execute a registered script from $global:DevRunScripts registry.
Retrieves and executes a script previously registered via Add-DevScript or Invoke-DevRun. Useful for re-running saved scripts, chaining scripts, or building workflows.
Script is executed in the current PowerShell session with access to all variables and modules.
Script name to execute (must exist in registry).
Update metadata (timestamp, exit code) after execution.
Return execution result objects.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Script name to execute (must exist in registry).
Update metadata (timestamp, exit code) after execution.
Return execution result objects.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Script must be registered via Add-DevScript or Invoke-DevRun first. Updates $LASTEXITCODE based on script execution.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-DevScript -Name "build" Executes the 'build' script from registry

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-DevScript -Name "test" -UpdateMetadata Executes 'test' script and updates timestamp/exit code

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $results = Invoke-DevScript -Name "analyze" -PassThru Executes script and captures output

maml:description.maml:para: Execute multiple registered scripts in sequence.
Executes a chain of registered scripts in order. Useful for multi-step workflows like build -> test -> deploy.
Can optionally stop on first failure or continue through all scripts.
Array of script names to execute in order.
Continue executing remaining scripts even if one fails. Default: stop on first failure.
Update metadata (timestamp, exit code) for each script after execution.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Array of script names to execute in order.
Continue executing remaining scripts even if one fails. Default: stop on first failure.
Update metadata (timestamp, exit code) for each script after execution.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: All scripts must be registered before chaining. Returns summary of executions.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-DevScriptChain -Names @("build", "test", "deploy") Executes build, then test, then deploy. Stops if any fails.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-DevScriptChain -Names @("lint", "format", "build") -ContinueOnError Executes all three scripts even if one fails

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-DevScriptChain -Names @("build", "test") -UpdateMetadata Executes scripts and updates their metadata

maml:description.maml:para: Execute a script block with a timeout, using PowerShell-conventional error handling.
Wraps script block execution in a timeout mechanism using PowerShell jobs. Designed for use in command chains where a problematic step might hang.
Follows PowerShell conventions: - Outputs directly to pipeline on success
- Throws terminating errors on failure or timeout
- Respects -ErrorAction parameter for error handling
- Integrates with try/catch and -ErrorVariable
The script block to execute with timeout protection.
Timeout duration in seconds. Default: 30 seconds.
Arguments to pass to the script block.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
The script block to execute with timeout protection.
Timeout duration in seconds. Default: 30 seconds.
Arguments to pass to the script block.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

dev:type.maml:name: Direct pipeline output from the script block on success.

maml:alert.maml:para: Implementation uses PowerShell jobs for true timeout capability. Job overhead: ~100-200ms startup cost.
Error Types: - System.TimeoutException: Execution exceeded timeout duration
- System.InvalidOperationException: Script block execution failed
Error Handling: - Default: Terminating errors (stops execution)
- With -ErrorAction Continue: Non-terminating (pipeline continues)
- With -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue: Suppressed (no error output)
- With try/catch: Can catch and handle programmatically
Design Philosophy: - Pipeline-first: Output flows naturally without property access
- Standard errors: Follows PowerShell error handling conventions
- Composable: Works seamlessly with AgentBlocks functions
- Debuggable: Error messages include duration and source info
Performance Considerations: - Job creation overhead makes this unsuitable for sub-second timeouts
- For batch operations, consider wrapping entire batch vs.
each item - Error messages include execution duration for performance analysis

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Invoke-WithTimeout { python slow_script.py } -TimeoutSeconds 10 | Find-Errors
Execute a potentially slow command with 10-second timeout, piping output to Find-Errors.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
-------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Invoke-WithTimeout { flaky-command } -ErrorAction Continue | Find-Errors
Continue pipeline even if command fails or times out.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-WithTimeout { dotnet build } -ErrorVariable buildErrors -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | Find-Errors

dev:remarks.maml:para: Capture errors in variable for inspection without stopping pipeline.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 5 --------------------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: $results | Format-Count } catch [System.TimeoutException] { Write-Warning "File read timed out - file too large" } catch { Write-Warning "Other error: $_" }
Handle timeout vs. script failure differently using typed exception catching.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 6 --------------------------

maml:description.maml:para: Count occurrences and sort by frequency.

Counts how many times each unique item appears in the input stream and returns results sorted by frequency (most common first). This is effectively Group-By with a more intuitive name for frequency analysis tasks.
Particularly useful for analyzing error messages, log entries, or test failures to quickly identify the most common issues.
Optional property to group by. If omitted, groups by the entire object.
Items to count. Each unique item becomes one result row.
Sort by frequency ascending (least common first) instead of descending.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Items to count. Each unique item becomes one result row.
Optional property to group by. If omitted, groups by the entire object.
Sort by frequency ascending (least common first) instead of descending.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: This is an alias-style wrapper around Group-By for better discoverability. Use this when your intent is frequency analysis rather than general grouping.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: "error", "warning", "error", "info", "error" | Measure-Frequency 3x: error 1x: warning 1x: info

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-Content build.log | Select-String "error:" | Measure-Frequency 42x: error: Cannot find module 12x: error: Undefined variable 3x: error: Type mismatch

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-Process | Measure-Frequency -Property ProcessName | Select-Object -First 5 15x: chrome 8x: node 5x: pwsh 3x: code 2x: explorer

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Import-Csv errors.csv | Measure-Frequency -Property ErrorCode | Format-Count -Width 4 245x: E001 89x: E042 12x: E404

maml:description.maml:para: Remove script from $global:DevRunScripts registry.
Removes script metadata from global registry. Useful for cleanup or removing obsolete scripts.
Does not affect cached stream data (use Clear-DevRunCache for that).
Script name to remove.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Script name to remove.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Does not check for dependencies - other scripts may reference removed script.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Remove-DevScript -Name "build" Removed script 'build' from registry

maml:description.maml:para: Export learned patterns and state to .brickyard.json file.

Saves the current BrickStore state (patterns, results, chains) to a JSON file in the project directory. This allows patterns learned for a specific project to persist across sessions and be shared with team members.
The .brickyard.json file can be committed to version control to share learned patterns with other developers or AI agents working on the project.
Output file path. Defaults to .brickyard.json in current directory.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Output file path. Defaults to .brickyard.json in current directory.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: File is human-readable JSON for easy review and editing. Includes metadata: created date, pattern count, etc.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Save-Project Saved 15 patterns to .brickyard.json

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Save-Project -Path "config/brickyard.json" # Save to custom location

maml:description.maml:para: Select Nth column from delimited text.
Extracts a specific column from delimited text (whitespace, comma, tab, etc.). Useful for parsing structured log output, CSV-like data, or tabular command output.
Column numbers are 1-indexed (first column is 1). Supports negative indexing (-1 for last column, -2 for second-to-last, etc.).
Column number to extract (1-indexed). Use negative numbers to count from end.
Text line to parse.
Delimiter pattern. Default is whitespace (\s+). Use ',' for CSV, '\t' for TSV, etc.
Trim whitespace from extracted value. Default is $true.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Text line to parse.
Column number to extract (1-indexed). Use negative numbers to count from end.
Delimiter pattern. Default is whitespace (\s+). Use ',' for CSV, '\t' for TSV, etc.
Trim whitespace from extracted value. Default is $true.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Returns $null if column doesn't exist. Use Select-Object -First N | Select-Column for preview of large files.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: "ERROR 2024-11-15 Database connection failed" | Select-Column 1 ERROR

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-Content access.log | Select-Column -Column 4 # Extract 4th column from each log line (e.g., HTTP status code)

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: "apple,banana,cherry,date" | Select-Column -Column 3 -Delimiter "," cherry

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: "one two three four" | Select-Column -Column -1 four

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 5 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-Content errors.txt | Select-Column 2 | Measure-Frequency # Count frequency of values in 2nd column

maml:description.maml:para: Select data using regular expressions with named groups.

Applies a regex pattern to input text and extracts data into PSCustomObject properties based on named capture groups. This enables structured data extraction from unstructured text like log files, compiler output, or API responses.
Named groups in the pattern become properties on the output object. For example, pattern '(?<file>\S+):(?<line>\d+)' creates objects with 'file' and 'line' properties.
Supports both single-match and multi-match modes. By default, returns first match per input line. Use -All to extract all matches.
Regular expression pattern with named groups. Example: '(?<key>\w+)=(?<value>\S+)'
Text to search. Can be string or object with ToString() method.
Specific named group to extract as simple string (instead of full object).
Extract all matches instead of just the first match per line.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Text to search. Can be string or object with ToString() method.
Regular expression pattern with named groups. Example: '(?<key>\w+)=(?<value>\S+)'
Specific named group to extract as simple string (instead of full object).
Extract all matches instead of just the first match per line.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Returns PSCustomObject for easy pipeline processing and filtering. Unmatched lines are skipped (no output for non-matching input).

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
"app.js:42:15: error: undefined variable" | Select-RegexMatch -Pattern '(?<file>[\w.]+):(?<line>\d+):(?<col>\d+): (?<msg>.+)'
file line col msg ---- ---- --- --- app.js 42 15 error: undefined variable

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-Content errors.log | Select-RegexMatch -Pattern 'ERROR: (?<message>.+)' -Group message Database connection failed Invalid API key Timeout after 30 seconds

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
"key1=value1 key2=value2" | Select-RegexMatch -Pattern '(?<key>\w+)=(?<value>\S+)' -All
key value --- ----- key1 value1 key2 value2

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-Content build.log | Select-RegexMatch -Pattern '(?<file>[\w/\\.-]+)\((?<line>\d+),(?<col>\d+)\): error (?<code>\w+): (?<msg>.+)' # Extracts structured error data from MSBuild output

maml:description.maml:para: Select text between two marker strings.
Extracts substring between start and end markers. Useful for parsing structured text like XML-ish formats, quoted strings, or delimited sections in logs.
Supports greedy (longest match) and non-greedy (shortest match) modes. Default is non-greedy to extract first occurrence.
Starting marker string. The marker itself is excluded from output.
Ending marker string. The marker itself is excluded from output.
Text to search.
Use greedy matching (extract longest possible match). Default is non-greedy.
Include start and end markers in the output.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Text to search.
Starting marker string. The marker itself is excluded from output.
Ending marker string. The marker itself is excluded from output.
Use greedy matching (extract longest possible match). Default is non-greedy.
Include start and end markers in the output.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Returns $null for lines without both markers. For nested markers, use -Greedy carefully or process with regex instead.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: "The quick brown fox" | Select-TextBetween -Start "" -End "" quick

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: 'Error: "file not found" in module' | Select-TextBetween -Start '"' -End '"' file not found

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-Content log.txt | Select-TextBetween -Start "[ERROR]" -End "[/ERROR]" # Extracts error details between markers

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: "start{outer{inner}outer}end" | Select-TextBetween -Start "{" -End "}" -Greedy outer{inner}outer

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 5 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: "start{outer{inner}outer}end" | Select-TextBetween -Start "{" -End "}" outer{inner

maml:description.maml:para: Capture pipeline input to environment variable while passing through.
Tee-style function that stores all pipeline input to an environment variable while simultaneously passing all items through to the next pipeline stage.

Forces full enumeration to guarantee all items are captured, then returns all items for continued processing. Useful for non-destructive analysis where you want to capture full output while still allowing downstream filtering.
Environment variable name (without $ env: prefix).
Pipeline input to capture and pass through.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Pipeline input to capture and pass through.
Environment variable name (without $ env: prefix).
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Use -Verbose to see items as they're captured. Stored as Out-String formatted text for easy retrieval and analysis.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-Process | Set-EnvironmentTee -Name "procs" | Select-Object -First 5 Captures all processes to $env:procs, displays first 5

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Invoke-DevRun -Script 'dotnet build' -Name build PS> Get-StreamData build Error | Set-EnvironmentTee -Name "build_archive" | Find-Errors | Show -Top 10 Archives full output, shows top 10 errors

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: "error","warning","error","info" | Set-EnvironmentTee -Name "test" -Verbose | Measure-Frequency VERBOSE: Tee: error VERBOSE: Tee: warning VERBOSE: Tee: error VERBOSE: Tee: info VERBOSE: Stored 4 items to $env:test

maml:description.maml:para: Display formatted summary of Invoke-DevRun stream data.
Shows frequency analysis summary for selected PowerShell streams from Invoke-DevRun results. Displays count, unique count, and top items for each requested stream.
Mimics Invoke-DevRun's built-in summary but allows custom stream selection and post-hoc analysis.
Name used in Invoke-DevRun (e.g., "build" for Invoke-DevRun -Name build).
Streams to include in summary. Default: Error, Warning (matches Invoke-DevRun default).
Number of top items to show per stream. Default: 5.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Name used in Invoke-DevRun (e.g., "build" for Invoke-DevRun -Name build).
Streams to include in summary. Default: Error, Warning (matches Invoke-DevRun default).
Number of top items to show per stream. Default: 5.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Requires Invoke-DevRun to have been executed with stream storage enabled (default behavior). Use Get-StreamData for raw stream access and custom analysis pipelines.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Show-StreamSummary -Name "build" Errors: 3 (2 unique)

dev:remarks.maml:para: Top Errors: 2x: file.cs(10): error CS0103 1x: file.cs(42): error CS0168

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Show-StreamSummary -Name "build" -Streams Error,Warning,Verbose

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Show-StreamSummary -Name "test" -Streams Error -TopCount 10

maml:description.maml:para: Stop background process and move output to DevRun cache.

Stops background process started with Invoke-BackgroundProcess and moves captured output to DevRun cache ($global:DevRunCache) for analysis with Get-StreamData, Get-BuildError, Group-BuildErrors, and all other Base/AgentBlocks functions.
After stopping, output is stored in $global:DevRunCache using the same format as Invoke-DevRun, making background process output compatible with all Base/AgentBlocks analysis functions.
This makes background process output fully compatible with Invoke-DevRun workflows.
Name of background process to stop.
Keep temporary output files (don't clean up). Useful for debugging.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Name of background process to stop.
Keep temporary output files (don't clean up). Useful for debugging.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Output stored in DevRun cache ($global:DevRunCache) under key Name. Compatible with all Base/AgentBlocks analysis functions.
Returns summary with error counts and top errors (like Invoke-DevRun).

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Stop-BackgroundProcess -Name 'devserver' Get-StreamData devserver Error | Find-Errors | Group-BuildErrors | Format-Count

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: # Stop and analyze build errors with regex + fuzzy hybrid Stop-BackgroundProcess -Name 'build' Get-StreamData build Error | Group-BuildErrors | Format-Count

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: # Stop and analyze with custom pattern Stop-BackgroundProcess -Name 'server' Get-StreamData server Output | Select-RegexMatch -Pattern 'Listening on: (?<url>https?://[^\s]+)' | Select-Object -ExpandProperty url

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: # Keep temp files for debugging Stop-BackgroundProcess -Name 'test' -KeepFiles

maml:description.maml:para: Check status of background process.
Returns process information if running, or stopped status if completed. Useful for monitoring multiple background processes or checking if process is still active before stopping.
Name of background process to check.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Name of background process to check.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: Returns PSCustomObject with Running, PID, CPU, Memory, Runtime, Command properties. If process not found or has ended, Running is $false.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Test-BackgroundProcess -Name 'devserver'
Name Running PID CPU MemoryMB Runtime Command ---- ------- --- --- -------- ------- ------- devserver True 12345 2.5 125.34 00:05:23.4567890 dotnet run --project Server.csproj

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: # Monitor multiple processes 'server','worker','watcher' | ForEach-Object { Test-BackgroundProcess -Name $_ }

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------

maml:description.maml:para: Update metadata for registered script.
Updates timestamp, exit code, or dependencies for an existing registered script. Script text is not modified.
Useful for tracking re-runs or updating dependencies.
Script name to update.
New exit code value.
Update timestamp to current time.
New dependencies array (replaces existing).
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Script name to update.
New exit code value.
Update timestamp to current time.
New dependencies array (replaces existing).
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

maml:alert.maml:para: At least one update parameter must be specified.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Update-DevScriptMetadata -Name "build" -ExitCode 0 -UpdateTimestamp Updated metadata for script 'build'
